There should be 0 such attributes, although maybe one slipped in around... Shadow parts, IIRC? Because rniwa hated DOMTokenList or something like that, so we just gave up on getting consensus for how to reflect it?

content.body: sideshowbarker: do you know if the old CVS history for specifications can still be found somewhere?
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: do you know if the old CVS history for specifications can still be found somewhere?

content.body: annevk: For W3C specs, I think no — not any longer. Not the original CVS history itself at least. because since CVS is a client-server thing, W3C would need have the CVS server running — or at least have the filesystem thing that CVS served from still saved.
content.formatted_body: annevk: For W3C specs, I think no — not any longer. Not the original CVS history itself at least. because since CVS is a client-server thing, W3C would need have the CVS server running — or at least have the filesystem thing that CVS served from still saved.

content.body: Well, with the exception of anything that we served from www.w3.org or w3.org URLs — that all still exists in CVS. (And is still being added to — W3C is still using CVS to maintain large parts of w3.org content, and till adding to it via CVS.)
Does anyone still have a copy that they could stuff in a git repository somehow?
It depends on which spec
If it were served from dev.w3.org org, then yeah I think we could manage to find copies.
Web Crypto came up above.
OK
I will do some digging

Given that for dev.w3.org at least, I think you remember that in the pre-github days, we (in many cases, me) migrated all of dvcs.w3.org content to Mercurial. So that still may exist somewhere — at least in local clones (maybe some things even on my own laptop).
sideshowbarker: the Mercurial copy I found suggests there's more history in CVS; they started anew
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: the Mercurial copy I found suggests there's more history in CVS; they started anew
